content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. This graph represents Andre’s distance from his bicycle as he walks in a park.


Decide whether the following statements are true or false.

  1. The graph has multiple horizontal intercepts.

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activit ies 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is True. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A horizontal intercept of the graph represents the time when Andre was with his bike.

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is True. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A maximum of the graph is the point (17,1)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is false. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph represents the temperature, in degrees Fahrenheit, as a function of time. 

 

At what hour in the afternoon does the maximum of the graph occur? Do not enter commas or spaces in your answer.

Correct! 3 p.m.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 3 p.m. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Match each feature of the situation with a corresponding statement in function notation.

    1. \(h(0)= 7\)

Correct! Starting height

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Starting height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(h(1.5)\)

Correct! Minimum height

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Minimum height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(h(4)\)

Correct! Maximum height

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Maximum height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(h(t)=6\) for \(7 ≤t ≤8\)

Correct! Height staying the same

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Height staying the same. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph of \(f(x) =x^2\) is provided.

    1. What is \(f(2)\)?

Correct!  The value of \(f(x)\) when x is 2 or \(f(2) = 4\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 4.6.2-4.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the value of \(f(x)\) when \(x\) is 2 or \(f(2) = 4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(f(1)\)?

Correct! f(1) = 1

Try again.Why don't you go back to activities 4.6.2-4.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(1) = 1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Shannon is running on a flat, rocky trail that eventually rises up a steep mountain. The graph below represents the total distance she covers with respect to time.

    2. How many miles does Shannon run in 60 minutes? 

Correct! 3 miles

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3 miles. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
